rules.text:
Be Polite.
Don't be rude to anyone. That's not welcome here. If someone is rude, then report the post and account so that the moderators can handle it.
No racism, sexism, homophobia, transphobia, xenophobia, anti-Semitism, or casteism (including targeted misgendering, deadnaming, or promotion of so-called "conversion therapy").
Do not post about inflammatory, controversial subjects without a Content Warning.
Do not post adult content, including pictures containing nudity, or unwelcome sexual attention (including sexualized comments or jokes).

records.text: Söka has a bunch of intents right now such as "Open bucket list" or "Open goal". In both instances, they open the app and display the list/goal, while also returning a value (simply the name of the goal/list).However after reading some articles and watching this year's videos, I'm wondering if these intents should be pure "Get" intents (eg. they don't open the app). But I'm finding it hard to see the value in just returning the name, or any other primitive type for that matter.

records.text: I’m impressed with the predictive code completion in the Xcode beta. I’ve been startled a few times when it knew exactly what I was typing. It took a little time to get over the eerie sensation, and then a little less time to accept the confirmation of my unoriginality, but now I’m excited by this tool. I do want to get better at knowing when to quickly accept the suggestion, and when to ignore the suggestion without getting distracted during those times when I’m not in harmony with it.

records.text: Honestly there’s only one thing I’m still struggling with: the macOS app is “more multi column” than Ivory, which has two consequences:- Expanding a window’s width does not enlarge the timeline;- Tapping a post opens in a separate column, and then it stays there when sliding up.So I’d say Mona > Ivory on iOS and iPad, but Ivory > Mona on Mac.I am honestly surprised that, with so many customization options, those two are the unchangeable defaults.

records.text: Subscribing to my notification on my SwiftUI view I can reset the viewContext and trigger a re-fetch. (Doing that currently by passing a UUID to the init method of the subview that fetches, so when changed it will re-fetch. Is there a method on an @FetchRequest though to just refetch?)However, views down the navigation path that had managed objects passed to them as @ObservableObjects are of course now holding references to invalid objects. Maybe every view needs to fetch the object directly?

records.text: That’s needed because simply processing the transactions still doesn’t update the ViewContext. Looking at Apple’s sample project associated with their WWDC 2022 session on using Core Data with CloudKit, I see that after they have integrated the changes they are calling `.reset()` on their viewContext (which invalidates all objects in memory) and then re-fetching.I don’t love resetting the context, but maybe that’s required, there’s no alternative? It’s also not a SwiftUI sample project. 2/3

It’s also not a SwiftUI sample project. 2/3
